Class Coin

  • java.lang.Object
    • Coin

  • public class Coin
extends java.lang.Object
    The Coin class defines a coin that can be flipped to either heads or tails. The object stores the number of coin flips and how many heads/tales are flipped. The coin can also be biased toward a certain side, but by default it is a fair coin. Class is tested using the Driver class.

      • Coin

        public Coin()
        No-Arg constructor for Coin. Instantiates and sets all values to neutral starting values.

        Precondition(s):

        • none

        Postcondition:

        • Class variables instantiated

      • Coin

        public Coin(java.lang.String name)
        Parameterized (1-parameter) constructor for Coin. Instantiates and sets all values to neutral starting values, except name, which is set to the given name parameter. The coin is then assigned a value using assignValue().

        Precondition(s):

        • none

        Postcondition:

        • Class variables instantiated, and;
        • name is set to given parameter, and;
        • value is set to appropriate value using assignValue()
        See Also:
        assignValue()

      • Coin

        public Coin(java.lang.String name,
            java.lang.String upFace)
        Parameterized (2-parameter) constructor for Coin. Instantiates and sets all values to neutral starting values with previous contstructors, except name, which is set to the given name parameter, and upFace, which is set to the upFace parameter. The coin is then assigned a value using assignValue().

        Precondition(s):

        • none

        Postcondition:

        • Class variables instantiated, and;
        • name is set to given parameter, and;
        • upFace is set to given parameter, and;
        • valye is set to appropriate value using assignValue()
        See Also:
        assignValue()

      • flip

        public java.lang.String flip()
        "Flips" coin, randomley assigning variable upFace to "heads" or "tails". The bias variable can weight the "flip." Uses the random() method of class Math to make the flip. Throws an error if the rand number is not an expected value. flip() then returns the value it changed upFace to.

        Precondition(s):

        • bias, upFace, setUpFace() instantiated
        • bias set to a value between 0 and 1

        Postcondition:

        • upFace set to new value based on flip, and;
        • new value of upFace returned
        Returns:
        heads or tails (or null if error)
        See Also:
        Math.random()

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overwrites toString() default method. Returns string with name and upFace instead

        Precondition(s):

        • name, upFace, getName(), getUpFace() instantiated

        Postcondition:

        • name and upFace returned
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
        String containing name and upFace

      • equals

        public boolean equals(Coin otherCoin)
        Checks if two coins' upFace values are equal

        Precondition(s):

        • upFace, getUpFace() instantiated
        • other Coin object instantiated

        Postcondition:

        • truth value for boolean expression return
        Returns:
        Boolean, if upFace's are equal

      • assignValue

        public void assignValue()
        assigns value to Coin based on name. Values for each name listed below. Throws error if value not valid

        • penny: 0.01
        • nickel: 0.05
        • dime: 0.10
        • quarter: 0.25
        • half-dollar: 0.50
        • dollar: 1.00

          • Precondition(s):

          • name, getName() instantiated
          • name set to valid value

          Postcondition:

          • value of Coin set to value that corresponds to name
